tool.name: AutoCycler Dotplot
tool.description: generate dotplot visualizations from assembly data
tool.command:
#import re
mkdir -p out_dir &&
mkdir assemblies &&
#set $identifier = re.sub('[^\w\-_\.]', '_', $input_file.element_identifier) ln -s '$input_file' 'assemblies/${identifier}' &&
autocycler dotplot --input 'assemblies/${identifier}' --out_png out_dir/dotplots.png --res '$res' --kmer '$kmer'

param.name: input_file
param.label: Input fasta/gfa file
param.help: all sequences in a FASTA or GFAfile

param.label: Image resolution
param.help: Size of dotplot image in pixels (default: 2000)

param.label: K-mer size
param.help: K-mer size used for dotplot generation (default: 32)

tool.help:
**AutoCycler Dotplot Tool**
Autocycler dotplot generates pairwise dotplots for input sequences. This can help to illuminate the differences between sequences and potential structural errors.
**Inputs**
- Input file (GFA or FASTA format) or collection containing assembly data
**Parameters**
- Image resolution: Size of output image in pixels (500-10000, default: 2000) - K-mer size: Size of k-mers used for comparison (1-100, default: 32)
**Outputs**
- PNG image file showing dotplot visualization
**Notes**
- Blue for same-strand matches, red for opposite-strand matches. - Performance scales with sequence length (n) and sequence number (n2). - While Autocycler dotplot can be run on large sequences (e.g. a bacterial chromosome), it can be slow, especially if there are many sequences. - Text size is scaled to fit in the margins. This means that having too many sequences or very short sequences can be a problem, as it will cause the text size to be very small.
.. class:: infomark
**More Information**
- `Autocycler dotplot`: https://github.com/rrwick/Autocycler/wiki/Autocycler-dotplot
**Citations**
